title: Leading Population Health Improvement
text:
Since January 2021, I have served as the state public health officer and director of the California Department of Public Health. From January 2011 to December 2020, I was the health officer of the City and County of San Francisco and director of the Population Health Division at the San Francisco Department of Public Health.

Figure 1 further explores the impact of temperature on ozone level.


Code
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(airquality, aes(Temp, Ozone)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "loess"
)





Figure 1: Temperature and ozone level.







Plot function pair (x(u), y(u)). See Figure 2 for an example.


Code
using Plots

plot(sin, 
     x->sin(2x), 
     0, 
     2π, 
     leg=false, 
     fill=(0,:lavender))





Figure 2: Parametric Plots




By default Julia cells will automatically print the value of their last statement (as with the example above where the call to plot() resulted in plot output). If you want to display multiple plots (or other types of output) from a single cell you should call the display() function explicitly. For example, here we output two plots side-by-side with sub-captions:


Code
using Plots

display(plot(sin, x -> sin(2x), 0, 2))
display(plot(x -> sin(4x), y -> sin(5y), 0, 2))
